It is like coming home to your NY Pied a Terre. Nothing at the Lowell is complicated but just straightforward. The welcoming is personal and expedient, starting by the Doormen and the Receptionists. The Managers have sent Personal Invitations and Flowers to your suite. The Staff is Old School efficient and invisible. The bathrooms are just what a bathroom should be, large, bright and inviting with excellent toiletry, linens and amenities. The quality of the bed and the bedding is impeccable, the rooms are silencieuse and smell fraiche! There is an excellent steak house restaurant attach to it and the room service is fast without fuss. What more do you want?

title: Great Hotel!
text: Recently stayed and was pleasantly surprised. Love the boutique nature of the hotel, staff was helpful/friendly, rooms nicely appointmented/spacious and location is perfect.  Will definitely return when I come back to NYC. This will be my first choice.

title: Not impressed
text:
I had a very nice first impression of this hotel, the ambience felt classy and intimate and the staff were very friendly and welcoming. My room seemed fine but I always carefully check the cleanliness of the bed in any hotel I stay and here my bed failed that test miserably, when I swiped my finger next to the mattress my finger got covered with dust. I called the front desk who sent housekeeping who straight away agreed that this wasn't acceptable and they suggested that I move to another room. I went to the gym and asked that they sort out my move in the mean time and 1 hour later I changed rooms. When I was going to bed I was going to plug in my phone charger behind the night table and as I touched the floor my entire hand was covered with filth, I went down to the front desk to show them and they were shocked when they saw my hand. This was an amount of filth that it would take at least one month to build up which means that the hotel didn't have a process to clean the room properly and also didn't have a policy to inspect the rooms properly which I found very concerning. Furthermore I find it absolutely unbelievable that after the hotel has seen and agreed that my bed was filthy and they had more than 1 hour to sort out a new room they still didn't ensure that my new room was clean. So after midnight, jet lagged and extremely tired, I was again moving rooms. My new room was an upgraded room which was nice and it was perfectly clean as far as I could tell.

The next morning I went down to breakfast, the breakfast room was very elegant but it took half an hour before I received my English breakfast which is too long in my opinion and when my breakfast arrived my poached eggs (requested medium) disintegrated into an under cooked watery egg soup which would have been inappropriate even if I would have requested my eggs to be very runny. The next morning I decided to have my breakfast delivered to my room and I decided to go for the healthy option, instead I got a continental breakfast delivered so again I was waiting for my breakfast to be delivered and was told that the manager had accidentally pressed the wrong button. The morning after that I received the breakfast that I ordered but it was delivered late. The final morning my breakfast was delivered without problems and I also had 2 room service dinners both of which were nice. In fairness to the hotel I should mention that a bottle of wine was sent to my room after they mixed up my breakfast order. Finally I didn't receive all my LHW benefits at this hotel.

The thing is that while I did find the service to be unbelievably sloppy on several occasions the staff were so friendly that it was hard to get really mad at them. The rooms (when properly cleaned) were very nicely appointed but considering the price tag and the quality of service that I received 3 out of 5 is still probably a generous rating.

title: Perfect stay
text: Excellent hotel on a quiet street off Madison Avenue. The room and especially the bathroom was very spacious and comfortable. Service is impeccable. Room service was also amazing. We can't wait to stay at the Lowell hotel again.

title: Absolutely lovely!
text: What a find on the East Side.  I had a lovely stay with an unexpected and fabulous upgrade.  The room was spacious (especially compared to most other NYC hotels) and well appointed. I really felt "at home" and cannot wait to plan another visit to the Lowell.  Two glorious nights on a business related trip - I couldn't wait to get back to the hotel at the end of the day to relax!  Front desk and restaurant staff were all excellent, attentive without smothering.  A perfect stay!

title: Beautiful,Clean and Spacious!  Great Location.
text: Booked this hotel on expedia and was pleasantly surprised to be upgraded to a bigger room upon checkin.  The personal escort from a receptionist to my room was a first time.  The room was beautiful and spacious...the bathroom was huge!  I loved this hotel.  I wanted to stay a second night BUT the hotel wouldn't honor the expedia price :( Bummed about that...but would still go back!!!

title: Perfect Location, Great for Business
text: I stayed at The Lowell Hotel last week for 4 nights for business. The location could not be better...Upper East side, within walking distance to some great shopping and restaurants.  But it was the staff that made this visit so charming.  The concierge, bellman, and room service gentlemen could not have been more helpful and friendly.  The room was warm and inviting, the bathroom was spotless and quite large, not to mention a little kitchenette - in NYC!  I would recommend for leisure, business or any time you're in New York - a great little, boutique, charming property!!

title: A luxury hideaway in New York
text: We stayed at the Lowell for three days prior to joining a cruise. It was recommended by friends and they were spot on. It is the best boutique city hotel we have ever stayed at. Situated near the corner of 63rd and Madison it is a stones throw to Central Park and Fifth avenue. It is a small family operated hotel that sets new standards in presentation, service and luxury. Our suite was huge (a rarity in New York) and included a separate living/ Dining area, a small kitchen, spacious bedroom and beautifully styled bathroom. But, the standout was the fireplace. A real, fireplace that the staff will prepare, on request, with selected scented timber logs. If only the weather had been cooler, we would have had a crackling fire in the evening and a bottle of red. Glad we have found this gem. It will be our first choice on our next trip to NYC

title: Wonderful small jewel
text: I spent just one night in the Lowell. I always try to book via law.com, and I prefer the Upper East Side. The Lowell is a very small hotel. There is no big lobby, and the floors are pretty small, too. One should love this private atmosphere. The service was overwhelming. The room was in best shape, in a timeless American design. Only the air-conditioning was noisy, which should´t be. The bathroom was huge, in white marble. Unfortunately, I missed to try the gym and the breakfast. But if you look for a quiet, privat hotel, the Lowell is the right place. In a city that never sleeps it is a place to find a rest and refresh for the adventures in the city jungle.

title: Perfection
text: I can not fault this fabulous hotel. It embraces you and welcomes you with a warm  smile. From the lovely friendly door man, to the helpful caring front desk...nothing is too much trouble and everything is done without what seems, any effort. It really is unique and a gem !!

title: Best Hotel in NYC
text:
The Lowell has set the standard for all my subsequent hotel experiences, which none have ever passed and few have reached its height.

Where to begin… It caress you with a warm touch, it soothes you with cozy, tasteful furnishings, it delights you with its first class decor. Whoever said "I want to live here", has spoken true; in an instant, it is your home, and you belong to it.

It is the best, most welcoming, romantic suite I have ever stayed in.

title: I want to live here
text: We love it here.  So intimate and calm and just so well done.  Very intimate lobby area, and the rooms are fabulous.  Our room this time was a deluxe jr suite with a terrace.  The front desk does a great job of securing transportation, theatre tickets, etc.  It feels like a private club.

title: Hidden Gem
text: What can I say...I love this hotel.  At check out, my husband and I regretted having to leave.  The entrance and the lobby are discreet.  The check in and check out were easy and fast.  The rooms are clean and well maintained.  The décor is cozy and soft.  The room was very comfortable and quiet.  Room service food was excellent and came on time. The dining room on the 2nd floor was lovely.  The location is very good - Madison & E 63rd.  I've stayed at a lot of different hotels in New York City (The Trump at Columbus Circle, The Plaza Athenee, New York Palace, The Palace, The London, Gramercy Park Hotel, and The Ritz Carlton CPS) and I have finally found the hotel for us.

title: Wonderful Hotel
text: This may be the best hotel experience I've ever had!  Property itself is immaculately maintained, and the rooms are spacious by NYC standards.  Mine even had a small kitchenette.  Well supplied gym, with complimentary sports drinks and power bars.  Staff is very welcoming and professional as well.  Can't say enough great things about it.

title: An understated and elegant home away from home....
text:
It's been two and a half years since my last review of The Lowell in NYC. Nothing has changed, which believe me is the ultimate compliment. This place is a jewel that we visit at least two times every year. That said, I would like to re-post my previous review. 

I believe we've been staying at the Lowell for approximately 15 years, usually visiting in the spring and fall. My wife and I have a favorite one-bedroom suite that we request, which is particularly nice in cool fall weather with its wood-burning fireplace. The suite has been totally renovated with a beautiful and spacious white marble bathroom and granite topped kitchenette. We use the Lowell as our base on these 5 night trips for forays to the theater, museums, restaurants and socializing with friends who are lucky enough to call NYC home. The Lowell is a welcome and ultra-comfortable respite from busy days and nights. We have also used it to host small cocktail gatherings in our suite, or order pizza up and watch a movie with friends. As I said, it feels like home and it's a tranquil and inviting respite to busy days and nights in the city. But above all, the real gems of the Lowell are its staff. These people are there to serve in a friendly and professional manner. They're down to earth, but exacting in executing your wishes and making you feel welcome and very special. From desk managers, to doormen, to bell men, to waiters and housekeeping, we see very little turnover from year to year. I assume the Lowell personnel are treated well, enjoy their jobs, and therefore reciprocate to their guests. The concierges, John Mark and Philip, are outstanding resources, well connected, and eager to advise and facilitate. The Lowell is a small hotel with approximately 4 rooms or suites per floor on 17 floors. It is an old building, but gracious and elegant. If you enjoy your hotels large, sleek, and bustling, this isn't what you're looking for. If you want highly personal attention, elegantly timeless ambience, and a stellar east side location between Park and Madison, this is your place. However, like most things dear and unique, it comes at a price, and it will get your attention depending on what type of accommodation you choose. But, that is a matter of choice, personal prioritiy and most likely frame of mind. The Lowell offers my wife and I everything we're looking for in NYC and we always look forward to coming back.

title: 5 Stars is not enough
text: I loved everything about this hotel!  The room was beautiful, the service amazing and the location ideal.  We have a small son and the hotel is only blocks from the Central Park Zoo, great restaurants, plenty of excellent shopping and Rock Center.  I can't wait to stay at the Lowell again with my family or on business travel.

title: Just like home
text: Stayed at The Lowell Hotel back in November for 10 days, just being like home. Think that is what I like the most. The tiny lobby where you are greeted by the guest relations team asking you how your day was and they mean it, they are genuinely interest in you. Love the breakfast, Patrick and his team is incredible and they really look after you, I could not have enough of blueberry pancakes every morning and that freshly squeezed grapefruit juice. Yum. The rooms are not the largest but with your own fireplace and bathroom with a window overlooking the skyscrapers of NYC compensates for the lack of space. The wardrobes are tiny but hey, its a studio and it feels like home.

title: Best hotel in NYC
text: I stayed at the lovely Lowell hotel last year and meant to write this review: as I was hurriedly packing my bags to run to the airport one of my bags split open (never learned how to pack properly) - I went to the front desk the the 2 reception women were so sweet and accommodating - they kept the broken bag while I ran to Bloomies to get another, then gave me an empty room to repack into the new bag and finally took care of the broken bag. The bellman was also helpful. The rooms and suites are gorgeous, clean, have every amenity, and the hotel is like a home away from home.

title: Peaceful Retreat
text: Great location in the city, but felt peaceful and quiet after hours of walking in the hubbub of NYC.  Upon our arrival, we were delighted to find a delicious afternoon tea available (we ate all of it!).  It felt like we were in London.  Rooms were a good size and very well maintained.  The management was helpful.  We would stay there again.

title: Excellant small hotel
text: This small hotel is tucked into a neighborhood just around the corner from nearly everything in NYC ~ fabulous location.  The rooms are spacious, clean and well appointed.  Staff is courteous and helpful.  Can't wait to visit again.

title: wow!!
text: Just stayed for a long week-end. The décor and service were beyond belief. The bathroom was about the size of my 1st apartment. The location was in one of the best (maybe the best) neighborhoods in the world-the whole world. Words cannot express how remarkable this place is. One pays a hefty price for all this, but it is worth it in this case.

title: Brunch excelente enquanto fazemos uma pausa nos passeios pelos arredores
text:
Não há como resistir. Um brunch no hotel boutique de luxo The Lowell é a pedida perfeita para a pausa na caminhada pelas lojas da Madison Avenue ou pelo Rockfeller Center ou Chrysler Building – tudo está muito próximo. O chá da tarde ou o brunch, este no final de semana, é servido no Pembroke Room, charmoso, com flores frescas nas mesas e atenciosidade ao servir. 
Com sua fachada art deco/moderna, o The Lowell é arquitetonicamente  significativo no histórico bairro de Upper East Side, uma área designada como um marco na cidade, e que tem sido recomendada pelo Conselho de Estado de New York para preservação histórica. Íntimo e luxuoso, é mantido em reconhecimento à rica história que contribuiu para estabelecer a sua notoriedade atual. Personalidades do cinema, CEOs e executivos do mundo da moda e design, editores de mídias reconhecidas e empresários frequentemente hospedam-se e apadrinham o hotel. Muito próximas estão lojas como Michael Kors, Hermes e Chopard e o aconchego do The Lowell tornou-se irrecusável para instantes de bem estar no intervalo do dia.

title: How Not To Make You Feel Special
text:
I booked two nights for my girlfriend's 30th birthday, as I was looking for something very special and exceptional. The hotel staff have an arrogant attitude which makes you feel anything but. I do need to add that the head of concierge and front door man were the exceptions.

We had a junior deluxe suite in an empty hotel, which was guaranteed as part of the booking. The hotel was aware that it was my girlfriend's 30th birthday and refused to upgrade us. In fact, they wanted to charge $500 a night for the next category room. The room itself was nice, simply because it had a beautiful fireplace (at a charge of $30 each time they lit it). However, we had a direct view of a rusty water tower, and I can only imagine the worst of its category. If this is how they treat people on a special occasion, I suggest going somewhere where you are actually welcomed. 

We did receive a cake and bottle of wine, which were nice touches, but we would have been much happier with a larger room. If we paid the amount they suggested, I highly recommend many other 5-star hotel experiences. 

Pluses: great location, beautiful reception area, and classic style. Minuses: We left feeling unwelcome by inhospitable and arrogant staff.

title: Style aseptisé -
text:
Bien plus cosy avant les travaux
Même style que partout ailleurs dans le monde
Dommage
The Library avait son style
Le lobby est maintenant comme n'importe quel lobby moderne
Un hôtel peut garder son style malgré des travaux de modernisation obligatoire
Par contre le service est parfait

title: Expensive. Stale petit fours. Hard Scones.
text: I was really excited for this place when my fiance and I went. Sadly it was very disappointing. Although the tea set up was pretty, the champagne was not good, the sandwich bread was a bit stale, almost all of the petit fours you can tell were not fresh. The best part of the place were the macaroons and they were not made at the Lowell. I was really disappointed because it was supposed to be a beautiful romantic anniversary tea with my love and I felt like there was little food for the $56.00 pricetag. The scones were not satisfying. If you want to spend a lot of money on mediocre food then go ahead, but I will never go back to this place. It is sad because I picked this one over the Plaza because I thought it would have better service and food. Which it didn't have either and there were not many people so you would think the service was better.  Disappointed :(

title: overrated
text: This hotel is good if you are above 50 years old . it feels a bit old. The location is great though.  It's located near the designer stores on Madison Ave. Hermes and Chopard are just around the corner. It's near enough to walk to the famous tourist spots but far enough to be isolated and private, which is a good thing. I suggest trip advisor to add another function to show the average age of the reviewers, as people of different age groups have different needs. The restaurant,  Pembroke room, is overrated. The decor needs some refurbishment. The caffe latte I ordered through room service turned out to be regular coffee that cost me almost usd30. The lobby is very small and dark. It doesn't feel very welcoming. You could say it feels like "home". The service is so so. No one showed me around the room.  The least they could do was to introduce me to the amenities , which is a standard in most luxury hotels. The junior suite I booked was pretty nice though.  It looks better in real than in the pictures.  Also,  I must commend the excellent service offered by the concierge , Mr John [--].  He was very friendly and helpful. He helped us book Broadway show tickets and even sent the confirmation with directions to the theater to our room. Housekeeping was very well done. They folded our clothes and organized them neatly for our convenience. Another thing I want to mention is the welcome email they sent a day prior to my arrival, something which they should have done earlier. I didn't see the point in sending that email, as it didnt serve any purpose. They asked if they could offer any help, and I replied requesting for pickup at the airport. But apparently by the time they got to the email, it was already too late to do anything. Also, they asked me about the things that I like and even my travel companion's name, which got me very excited as I was expecting a very grand welcome.  But the reality was far from that. If you are unsure of your ability to meet certain expectations , then don't set the bar so high because it's just very anti climax and disappointing. Even the hotels in bali could have done a much better job. Oh, and they broke my suitcase. Also, be careful of the bellboy, who solicited private car services at an exorbitant price. On my first outing to times square, which isn't very far away, I actually wanted to hail a cab but he recommended that I take a private car but when I got into the car and asked about the cost , it was too late to save myself the embarrassment of saying no. He asked if I was paying cash and I said yes. He then told me that it wouldn't make a difference if I took the private car, but the difference turned out to be more than triple of what I'd have to pay for the regular taxi. Maybe a rookie traveler to NYC like me should have known to be a bit more careful. To summarize my experience,  "old rich" with no wow factor.

title: Renovated Lowell Better Than Ever
text:
I stayed 4 nights in a newly remodeled room at the Lowell in November, 2013. I have stayed regularly at this hotel for years, but this was my first stay since renovations have been completed, bringing the hotel into the 21st century.

The room resulted from a major effort. Walls had been moved and the corner room was fresh, clean and bright. The bath had a new heated white marble floor and new marble walls to the ceiling. The shower was separate.

The renovation did not change the quiet, homey atmosphere of the hotel.

The lobby and the Pembroke Room have not yet been remodeled. Upgrades to those spaces are overdue. They look dated compared to my newly redone room. The adjacent restaurant is currently closed for remodeling which may be a prelude to a redo of the Pembroke.

title: My Favorite Hotel in NYC
text: I am a repeat guest, as the overall experience is the best.  I enjoy the location, as it is a true retreat from the chaos that you experience in the city.  You are able to walk in, stop, relax, take a calm breath.  The service could be a little better, as I've seen it decrease from the past.  The TV in the bathroom did not work.  Overall, I highly recommend it.

title: Small, Quiet, Luxurious Hotel
text:
We are frequent visitors to NYC and know the city well, but were unfamiliar with the Lowell.  The hotel has a tiny lobby.  Their main restaurant was closed due to renovation, so we can not comment on it.  The views from our room were not great; there was a courtyard surrounded by apartment buildings. You could see into the apartments.  So if you want a Jimmy Stewart "Rear Window" experience you would like our room.  

The reader must wonder why we rated the hotel very good, after the above description. The room was fabulous, with a great bathroom.  The room was quiet with a very comfortable bed. We had breakfast in the second floor dining room, where if you looked out the windows you would have a similar view to our room, but the food and the service were great.  Some may find the place stodgy, with tea in the afternoon, and very formal service, but that beats, "hello my name is Hepy Titus, and I will be your server today."

So in spite of the view from our room, the small lobby, and some of the patricians the frequented the place, the old world service and charm won us over.

title: A nice European style hotel, if you can afford it.
text:
My wife and i stayed one night for our anniversary. The location isn't right by anything very special but it was close to the private event that we were attending nearby. The prices are VERY high but similar to other high end hotels in the area.
It's a smaller european feel hotel. Everyone was very polite and polished. We were given a large brass key on a large tasseled keychain and escorted to our room. The hotel is very quiet and very clean. 
We had no problems with service and no sign of bedbugs (which can be a problem in New York City). The hotel offers valet service but there is a 10-15 minute wait at times as the garage is not right by the hotel.
The bed was very comfortable and we had a great night's sleep.

title: We can't wait to go back
text: My mom and I stayed at the Lowell in July 2013. Prior to our arrival, the Lowell contacted us and asked about our favorite drinks, which they had stocked in our room when we arrived. We were upgraded to a suite and our room was exceptional. The room itself was very large by NYC standards. The bed was super comfortable, the bathroom was luxurious, and everything was clean. The location was perfect for a girls shopping weekend- we were blocks away from all our favorite stores on Madison and Fifth, and walking distance from the theater district. Our room rate included breakfast in the Pembroke Room, which was delicious but would have been very pricey if it had not been included. We plan to return to the Lowell on our next trip to New York.

title: Beware the bait and switch
text:
The Lowell Hotel is well situated but like all refurbished properties - the room differences in like  categories are quite significant. Since the rooms are nose-bleedingly expensive, we have always checked and re-checked before staying there to make sure that our preference will be available, as we know the rooms in the hotel. On this occasion, we had called beforehand three times and were assured that there would be no problem.
When we arrived from our long flight, after checking in, we thought to ask and to our surprise,  were told that our preference was not available but that we had been allocated a room in the same category. Problem was that we knew the room in question and did not want to stay there,  as the room in question is right next to the elevator bank and looks out onto the street, which can be quite noisy at times. We were offered a late checkout or a reduction in rate as compensation, or a transfer to the same room on a higher floor. We did not want this, as we want quiet above all and the hotel knows this is the case, if they had looked at our record.
So now began our problems. The front desk manager was insolent, telling us that room allocation is always done after careful consideration daily of the list of expected guests, which showed that we obviously were not on the Lowell's list of guests considered worthy of consideration - and she appeared quite surprised that we wanted the category of room expected, which showed that she had not reviewed our record at all. Nor had any attention been paid to us as repeat guests, our room preference or the three phone calls leading up to our stay checking on the room category availability. Very quickly we decided, being tired and discomfited by this unwelcome reception, to go elsewhere - we went to the Carlyle, where we were warmly welcomed and had a good experience.
However, the Lowell management has not responded well. We felt that, after what had happened, the hotel management should either cancel or mitigate the room charge. The hotel Manager, Mr Verma, apologized most insincerely but suggested that not the Lowell staff, but we ourselves, had been insulting - which is absolutely not true - and that we were accusing him of lying about room availability, which is also not true. This line of polite confrontation allowed him to avoid completely a discussion about what had happened with our reservation. Instead of trying to work with us to leave us with an impression about the Lowell that could bring us back in future - he tried to put us in the wrong over the entire affair, which has made certain that we would never want to stay again. I told him that I was totally shocked that someone in hospitality could behave thus, but he clearly did not care one whit about my opinion.

title: QUE BUEN ROLLO
text: Un hotel explendido en plena manahattan he estado 3 días con mi familia, un oasis de tranquilidad y de lujo, las habitaciones son muy comoda y las camas son AMERICANAS osea super comodas. el servicio es excelente.

title:
Charming Lovely Small Boutique
Hotel 63rd and Madison
text:
The service, decor, cleanliness rooms, linens, everything about the Lowell is superb...it came highly recommended from friends who know NY.
This hotel is wonderfully situated and a absolute a treasure. Will not stay anywhere else when returning to NY.. I can not rate it high enough from the desk persons, to reservations to the concierge's.. Wonderful!!!

title: I love it!
text:
There' s so much high-octane hotel trumpet-blowing on the Upper East Side.So many bright llights,red carpets,pumped up restaurants with waiting lists.
And then there is th Lowell.With none of the above.It's so ,well,nondescript from the outside.There is no buzzo,no noise ,no scrum.This is where you come to pretend your very own Manhattan hideout and your staff are flipping brilliant.Where you retreat to kick off your shoes,curl up your log fire(yes your log fire) and order room service.
I love this place

title: Lovely luxury boutique on the East Side
text: Superb service. Elegant, well done food from room service. Excellent bed and beautifully appointed livingroom. Marble bath. Nothing is missing here. If you need trendy, a bar scene, and like to scout out fellow travelers, this is not for you.  This hotel is old, but thoroughly stylish, missing nothing, intensely private, and wonderfully quiet. It's an escape from the intensity of modern life in the city. You've got designer shopping on Madison Ave., and wonderful restaurant choices in the neighborhood. Yes, it's pricey. But you don't have the experience of accommodating yourself to the faults of the hotel. It accommodates you!

title: Lowell Hotel NYC
text: Stayed in many luxury hotels in NYC ....First stay in the Lowell. Building appearance is deceptive, very plain looking facade .. Typical small lobby and tiny elevators, service on arrival was great. Staff remembered my name after a few days and the hotel seems to have a clientele of regular returning guests. Like most places in NYC, there is construction on the street, but, the building seems to be very well insulated from the noise. Rooms were great, had an antique feel but with all modern conveniences. Top shelf linens and towels, fantastic water pressure.  Great neighborhood, short walk to Lexington Ave, markets and restaurants. Great hotel, will be back.

title: Wonderful, clubby luxury
text: This is a wonderful, clubby small luxury hotel.  For some trips and purposes, it is the best hotel in the City.  The rooms are spacious and well furnished, but not ostentatious. A very pleasant place to sit and read or discuss the next outing. The staff are quiet, completely competent and just friendly enough.  This hotel is a throwback to the 1920s, with a high level of personal service.  But, it isn't for everyone.  This is not high concept or high style in the modern sense.  The décor is clubby Victorian.  Your grandmother would think it wonderful, but your teenage daughter will likely prefer the edgier Crosby Street or one of the Trump properties.  Your European friends will be horrified.  However, for a couple's weekend to the City where you want to be on the East Side and want everything to be and work perfectly without drama, it was great for us.  From the lovely complimentary fruit bowel to the perfect coffee at breakfast, it was all just right.  The price is high, and there won't be anyone visible to share your ability to pay these rates with, but if that is what you want, you need to be at the Four Seasons.  No bar, but 24 hour room service.  All in all, one of our favorite places.

title: Second time around even better!
text: I talked my husband into staying overnight at The Lowell since we were attending an evening wedding. I had stayed at the hotel a couple of years ago and thought it was great but this time it surpassed"great!" My husband who is harder to please loved it too. The staff were so friendly and accommodating. Location was great and breakfast was delicious!

title: Now this is New York
text:
I'm not that familiar with New York, but I have an expectation of a bold style and service, especially in this part of the city.  The Lowell Hotel was in every measure a wonderful confirmation of that.  And if the Lowell is any glimpse of a top tier hotel in New York, then we're doing pretty good on the world stage.  I stayed two days & two nights at the Lowell for a relative's wedding, and from the first minute, I knew that I was going to be happy.  It is a quiet hotel with large clean rooms and a very helpful and attentive staff.  It is not a large hotel as such, but I was generally impressed with the layout, which made it very easy to walk around or get to your room quickly.  What struck me every time I walked in the lobby was how handsome the hotel is - not stodgy or old fashioned but long on class.  I've found my favorite hotel in New York.

Only complaint - the kitchenette was a little worn, and the kitchenette floor looked like it needs a cleaning.

Last thing.. I would go to the Lowell just to dine in the Pembroke room, and I mean it was terrific.

title: Tea at Pembroke Room and Staff are Top Notch
text: My Mother and I arrived in driving rain for Afternoon Tea at the Pembroke.  The front desk staff person was very accomodating to help us find a place to make our soggy selves presentable.  We then proceeded to the Pembroke. What a gracious, perfectly appropriate, relaxing, QUIET room!  Our waiter, Steve, was extremely knowledgeable about the teas and advised us well. Lowell Blend and Oolong teas, sandwiches, fruit tarts, and jams for the scones were our favorites.  We noticed that Steve, by himself, competently handled at least 5 tables with just the right amount of attention.  After a lovely tea time, we had to get to our next destination ASAP.  Still raining.  The doorman, Sergei, pursued cabs for several minutes IN HEAVY RAIN IN NYC and got us a wonderful car service, which smoothly wisked us away.  Sergei and Alex - OUR HEROES.  The decor and refined atmosphere of the Lowell are hard to outshine, however the Hotel Staff are the true stars of this wonderful hotel with their exceptional and cordial service.  Loved it.

title: No Room For Improvement
text: Everything is right for this beautiful boutique hotel.  From the luxurious floral arrangements upon your entrance to the understated elegance of the rooms and those spa-like bathrooms.  A real treat in the middle of Manhattan.

title: Afternoon tea at the Pembroke Room, The Lowell, New York City
text: My girlfriends and I recently enjoyed a wonderful afternoon tea at the Pembroke Room. The service was excellent and the room was very pretty. It is a small intimate room and I felt like we were in a jewel box at a small palace in France. For a group of 8 pr more , the group has to,select 3 teas, I suppose it helps make service more efficient. We picked themLowell blend, the Harmony and the Peat. Everyone loved the Lowell, nobody like the Pear. The staff kept our cups full and were very attentive.  We all had the classic tea and had a variety of petite sandwiches, pastries and scones. We each got 4 pieces of sandwiches, and two tiers filled with the pastries like macaroons,,tarts, petit fours. However we only got one tiny scone each ...it was too firm for my taste and really small. I wish we had way fewer pasties and more scones. I enjoy scones and have been to many different places, including England and this definitely did not have good scones. So, if you want an intimate , elegant room, and re not too picky with the scone, do come and enjoy this lovely place.

title: Secret gem of a hotel
text: It's funny that many of the reviews mention the fact that this hotel is not very well known! I can concur, as when I got to JFK and took a shuttle bus neither the bus driver or the computer with the list of hotels in NYC had heard of it. It has to be one of NYC's best kept secrets. Location is excellent for shopping, next to central park, 30 mins walk to many museums. Warm welcome on arrival with complimentary drinks. The room itself was large by NYC standards and beautifully decorated. Excellent bed and a quiet location lead to restful nights sleep. We never ate at the hotel with the exception of afternoon tea in our room, this too did not disappoint. Would recommend without hesitation.

title: Top class location, very good hotel
text: The hotel itself is charming with beautiful decor  and  the location is fabulous Our suite was tastefully decorated and spacious.  We stayed 5 nights and it truly felt like we had our own apartment in the city . Very courteous and polite service but a little bit impersonal.

title: Serenity on the Upper East Side
text: Perfect location for a visit to NYC.  Location is superb, steps away from shopping.  Everyone at the is very attentive, anticipate your needs each and every time.  They remember your name upon returning to the hotel, which is a nice touch.  The rooms are comfortable, very nice and comfortable for working in your room.

title: Home from home!   A serious treat!!
text:
This is the best kept secret in NewYork.    Outstanding 5 star boutique hotel.     Best location , excellent service and wonderful Michael J Smith designed suites and rooms.     You can light the fires in your suites - it is simply a dream.    Great room service and also room service from the chop house next door.    Try the Lemon Chicken!!    It never fails and spoils you for anywhere else. 
This was my 30th visit.

title: Like visiting an elegant home, with world class service.
text: Very brief but lovely stay this February.  The Lowell isn't flashy or ostentatious, but our room was beautiful, with a working fireplace and kitchen.  It felt like being house guests for the weekend with a very wealthy friend.   And awesome service, they even sent a welcome drink to our room.   A great choice for a romantic getaway or family vacation (Rooms with kitchens would be great for anyone with children.)  Not cheap, but worth a splurge.  Not quite sure about the room service menu for pets.... but am sure it gets used.

title: Amazing
text: I could easily run out of superlatives to describe this hotel. We were here for seven days in January and the whole experience was incredible from the moment that we arrived to the moment we left we were treated like royalty. I would have no hesitation in recommending this hotel to ANYONE. Superb.

title: Discrete Elegance
text:
At the opposite side of the same block than Hermes just off Madison, the location is cool.
The doormen are correct. The lobby is old NY understated and chic. The receptionists and the concierge makes you feel at home. The clientele is upscale, discrete and well travelled. You get to your floor rarely seeing anyones, and you get to a normal elegant well appointed suite. It's comfortable, the bed and the linens are very nice. Good lighting, quiet, with wonderful classic bathrooms and amenities. Is it all that anyone can ask for? Good room service, great valet and excellent housekeeping. And they are kind and generous with the hotel car, and plenty of perks... Good service is invisible, the Lowell knows!

title: Comme à la maison...
text:
Outre des chambres impéccables et un décor moderne mais qui respecte le style new yorkais (c'est agréable de se réveiller en sachant où l'on est!), les équipes du Lowell ont cultivé l'art de la gentillesse et du service qui va à la rencontre du client, sans se contenter de répondre à un besoin déjà exprimé.. le vrai luxe...!
Merci pour ces quelques jours très agréables.

title: Could not find a better New York Hotel if you tried!
text:
I do not know what the last reviewer is referring to, because I just spent 4 perfect nights at the Lowell.    Breakfast, afternoon tea and Room Service were all sampled, and all great.   The doormen and the Front Desk staff outstanding.   One valet chased a cab down the street for us, when I thanked him his response "that my job'", actually I thought, that is way beyond your job!!   Well Done.   Concierge hit every recommendation exactly.  The entire stay was a huge success.
Thank you Lowell team, I will be sure to come back.

title: Read this and you decide
text:
Booked the Lowell suite Excellent room.
after arriving went to dinner. When we returned a maint. man was leaving the room..when I questioned him he said " wrong room"
About an hour later door bell rang and before I could get to door he was coming in.
Left next morning and upon returning our phone charger was missing. After several people came to our room noting that they could not understand what happened. In the end the maint. Person had entered our room and removed the charger.
The GM called me to apologze and asked me to forgive this person for taking the charger. I guess the GM was O.K. with this employees action if I was.
This makes me very uncomfortable with management.
Ron

title: AWESOME
text: good job:) m happy ,,, m gonna spend som more dollars out of my pocket and it is always worth it and on top of that the quality staff and all the crew members were so polite and moreover kind enough to provide and cater your needs,i went alone and had a good time but trust me i will be along with ma g.f this feb so its gonna be interesting

title: In a word - perfect!
text:
Stayed at The Lowell over New Year's with the family. The place feels less like a hotel, and more like an upscale residence where staff knows exactly who you are and is ready to assist in a very genuine and non-obtrusive way. This is a rarity, even at most 5-star hotels.

The whole stay was fantastic -- the suite we were upgraded to was spacious and well furnished, the welcome gifts for the kids were a very nice touch and everybody from the valet to front desk, to waiting staff, to room service was extremely accommodating. Not to overlook, the bed was one of the most comfortable hotel beds I've slept on. (For those who will read this and think that I need to get out more, please read my other reviews).

Two things which deserve a special mention in my book:

- prior to arrival I received an email from Guest Relations asking about the names of all family members in my party, our likes and dislikes and allergy information; my kids (ages 9 and 11) were thrilled to see that small welcome gifts had their names

- my son wrote a thank you note to hotel staff and left it in the room; hotel General Manager sent him a letter acknowledging the note and welcoming the whole family back to The Lowell; I've traveled a lot with and without kids, but this is the level of attention that I have rarely seen, if ever

So, needless to say, we will be back.

title: Peaceful with terrific service
text: This was our first stay at this hotel.  Located in a residential area within a short walk from great shopping, this boutique is a gem.  Even though there is no lobby, there are lots of nice touches.  Hot cider or chocolate near the concierge desk served along side holiday cookies and welcome beverage delivered to the room on arrival.  The standard rooms are spacious with enough room for a work table, a side chair and plenty of space to accommodate a room service table setting for two people.  The bathroom is very l large with tub, separate shower and flat screen t.v.  What makes this property heavenly is that it is quiet allowing for a wonderful nights sleep.  We stayed on the fourth floor and it was very peaceful.   Room service was quick and the food was delicious.  Zero complaints.  I see no reason not to return to this property.  It's lovely.

title: This has to be one of the best hotels...anywhere
text:
When my NYC standby hotel was booked, I followed the reviews in Trip Advisor and booked this hotel as a substitute. I spent three days there with my wife and the hotel is an example of what an upscale hotel should be. Reception was warm and efficient. The one bedroom suite was striking in its decor and layout and it was spotless. The restaurant is small but perfect for breakfast with the food sublime. The baked goods were superb. Service is perfect with every staff member dedicated to fullfilling every request and whim of the guest. The Concierge is a model of perfection and booked several restaurants and services for us without a hitch.
Alas into every review a little rain must fall and there were 2 items missing in the room...phone books and an iron which we found strange but a small inconvenience.
I have traveled all over the world and stayed at so many great hotels and the Lowell has to be one of the top 10 hotels I have experienced.
One word of caution and that is that the Lowell is about 100 yards from Park Avenue and Park Avenue is one of the three avenues in NYC with 2 way traffic and it is almost always busy. For those who are bothered by routine traffic noise; this may prove bothersome. 
Other than this small point, you should experience this hotel's  luxury and the multitude of amenities that it offers.

title: A small oasis in the metropolis
text:
The Lowell Hotel has become the weekend getaway for my wife and I. The staff is
like family, and room service is impeccable in terms of presentation and quality. The beds are 
comfortable, and the bathrooms spacious. There is nothing standardized in the hotel so it feels like an actual home-- a big mansion with many rooms. I have even come to love the tiny but homey elevators!

title: First Class stay in NYC
text: I spent 4 nights at the Lowell Hotel.  It was perfection!  If you like a quiet, well run hotel that makes being in NYC relaxing, this is the place for you.  The staff is very professional and I could not have asked for anything more.  Beds are comfortable, they deliver any and all newspapers, the gym has everything one needs and the breakfasts are great.  Super location on the upper East Side.  It is a high priced spread but they do deliver good value.

title: Pembroke Room for Afternoon Tea is super!
text: The Lowell is a boutique hotel on New York's posh Upper East Side.  The real find, though, is the hotel restaurant's afternoon tea.  For $50 per person (not cheap but worth it) you are seated in an elegant room that could be a replica of a section of Buckingham Palace.  You order a choice of tea and receive scones, sandwiches of lobster salad and chicken, clotted cream, jam, the works.  The only tea service better than this in my experience was that of the Shangri-La Hotel in Hong Kong, which featured a pianist as well.  The best time to arrive is 3 p.m. and, if you don't like crowds, make the trip Monday through Thursday.

title: Another amazing stay at the Lowell!
text: We stayed with my wife at the Lowell again this year during our short trip to New-York city, and we had another tremendous and delightful experience. General Manager Ashish Verma and all his team are all working together to provide an amazing stay each time, with everyone doing their best to always exceed your expectations. Rooms are amazingly well designed and kept, bathrooms always a delight, you really feel pampered and well taken care of. Upon arrival, the butler will show you to your room, show you around and will make himself available till quite late. A small luxurious property with a very dedicated team delivering the best of New York's hospitality!

title: Great hotel, chic and quiet.
text: I went with my husband on April. A great Hotel! Loved it! Chic, quiet, great location. You can run into any celebrity without even noticing! The staff is great as well. One of the best in New York. We are definitely going back! Very nice restaurant to have dinner across the street!

title: STAY IF YOU CAN!!!
text:
I stayed in a nice junior suite on the 12 th floor .
A beautiful bathroom with 2 sinks ,  bathtub and a big comfortable shower and a nice  window.
I did not have a street view because the room  faced the back of the building, but on the other hand it was extremely quiet.The bed and the sheets were impeccable

The service is outstanding , you really feel that you are special.
It is very good for couples as it is for families.
The breakfast room is on the second floor, it has no view but it is really cozy.
and the best part, they do not have the usual buffet , that i personally hate.
The eggs stay there forever and the bread was touched by everybody!!
I love the fact that you order what you want and everything is just fresh!!

Location could not be better ,close to everything but at the same time it is on a side street.
It is really worth the money.
The decoration is elegant and at the same personal.
From the manager to the doorman you feel people are happy to work there.
I am counting the days to go back.

title: la mia Casa a New York.
text: Un piccolo scrigno nell'Upper East Side. Tutto perfetto, da sempre, camere e suite arredate con gusto ed immacolate. Reception e concierge assolutamente perfetti. Sala colazioni che è una piccola bomboniera. Piccola palestra. Non ha il ristorante ma ha a fianco il famoso Post House, di fronte il carinissimo bistro Bilboquet e sempre adiacente il Cigar Club Macanudo. Unica pecca... è carissimo!

title: Comfort in the East Side
text:
My family and I stayed for five days at the Lowell in April of 2012. We organized a two-bedroom suite for everyone, and I must say it was very, very comfortable. I thought the rooms were wonderful, with every amenity you can think of included - and I was happy to have a tiny kitchen as well.  Beds were comfortable, and weirdly enough, the hotel was really quiet - which was a new experience for me in New York!

As other reviewers have suggested, it really was like being at home in New York.

The best thing about the Lowell are the concierge team, hands down.  They were courteous, they were able to organize anything, they didn't kill you with crazy charges and if things were expensive, they were also able to offer alternatives if you wanted them.  Our family usually uses the concierge service a lot, so this was perfect for us.  I really appreciated both John Mark and Philip and I would go back just for them.

I was sad that we didn't have a view, but I think that is because I had asked for rooms with fireplaces; I wouldn't do this again because the fireplaces looked a bit shallow and I would have been afraid to have a fire in them, so when we go back I will try to book a suite if I can that has the outdoor area (I think it is a large covered balcony or something).  Since we used to stay at the Ritz at Central Park, we really love a great view, and I feel that we missed this. But this isn't something that the Lowell can be faulted with.

I didn't really love the restaurant/bar that is next door to the hotel and is attached to it with a door.  I felt that, on the one hand, it did have the feel of "old New York".  On the other hand, the bar is just a line bar that is set in the walkway to the restaurant, and it didn't look comfortable or inviting.  Surely there must be a way to make this place more like a place people want to have a drink before dinner?
The restaurant, in my opinion, could also use some sprucing up.  We had a better experience (thanks again to the concierge) at Le Billbouquet across the street.

Finally, the hotel breakfast room/small restaurant on the second floor was really weird.  I thought it was creepy the first time we were there because it is low and dark and furnished in an old-fashioned way. Later, I went down and had breakfast there, and it didn't seem so strange.  It was kind of cozy.  It is, again, more like a home than a hotel - which is a good thing.

All in all, I would go back. I loved the neighborhood setting as well.  You don't always have to be in the middle of everything all the time, and Lowell Hotel is a nice place to kick back and relax, knowing that you are steps away from anything you want or need at any time.

title: Excellent 5 star hotel close to Central Park and 5th Avenue
text: 5 star quality in everything! Excellent service, great rooms, great place to stay for special occasions.

title: I wish Margaret from reservations ran this hotel.
text:
I know my title may sound strange but I really believe if she did, it would truly be a notch above so many other hotels because of her attention to detail and customer service skills. I don't want to give this hotel a negative review, I wanted to like it as much as Margaret in reservations.  It is certainly not a bad hotel, but it has the potential to be a wonderful hotel.  In defense of the hotel, since I only stayed for one night, maybe I caught it on an "off" day.  I was coming to town for a Dr's appt and because I was so sick I needed my mother and her husband to drive me.  I had changed my reservation 3 times because my migraine was so bad and Margaret was very accommodating.  The day of my arrival I called to add a room to my reservation.  The rooms were around $750 and I was eligible for an upgrade because I am an Andrew Harper member.  Margaret made the smart suggestion that I upgrade my room for a couple hundred of dollars and then use the upgrade, and add on my parents room making it a two bedroom suite.  I thanked her for even thinking that up and was so excited about my stay.  The Andrew Harper rewards also entitled us to a bottle of wine, vip fruit basket, free afternoon tea and a continental breakfast.  When we arrived, around 3:30, they said the room wasn't ready and I thought, oh perfect we can go for tea, but we were told to wait in the waiting area, which we did.  After about 45 minutes we were taken to our room.  The living room was great, it was comfortable, newly re-finished, it had a terrace with a really interesting city view, if you hung over the balcony enough, you could even see central park.  I took the nicer bedroom, it had the same city view, a gorgeous bathroom with great amenities.  The carpet however was wet from being cleaned and had that weird chemical smell, if I didn't have a migraine, it would have been more livable for me.  The other bedroom was also nice, city view, but not as good as mine and it had a much smaller bathroom. But again, we were only there for one night.  We had room service for dinner and we were told that it would take approximately 45 minutes, it ended up closer to an hr and 45 minutes.  I hate confrontation, so does my mother, but my stepfather yelled at room service which embarrassed me greatly, they took care of the bill which I thought was more than generous (maybe it was part, I really stayed out of the whole thing, I hid in my bedroom).  The food was amazing, we had this awesome tomato soup, although it would have been better if it came with the gorgonzola crustini it was advertised with.  I had the fresh pea ravioli which was delicious. The VIP fruit basket was 3 apples.  No tea. There was no breakfast the following morning.  We were also charged a price higher than quoted.  Oh, and the lady who did the turn down was lovely I guess to some up.
Pros:
Margaret, Margaret, Margaret....
CIty view suite with terrace
room service

Cons:
Things are just not delivered as promised (I believe this is a customer service issue)
We were charged a price higher than we were quoted

Honestly, I wouldn't stay here again because I don't know what it would be like, this is my only experience with this hotel. It was overall just more disappointing than anything, it would have been better to expect nothing and be surprised along the way.

title: Sehr schönes kleines persönliches Hotel
text: Das ehemals zu Relais & Chateaux und heute zu The Leading Hotels of the World gehörende Hotel ist sehr schön und liegt sehr zentral in der Nähe des Central Parks. Der Service ist und die Hilfsbereitschaft ist ausgezeichnet. Das Frühstück ist gut. Die Kühlung der Minibar war aber deutlich zu laut. Aber man konnte sie einfach abstellen. Dadurch das das Hotel klein ist, ist die Betreuung sehr gut und sehr persönlich.

title: I could easily live there.
text: This warm, welcoming property is a panacea for the cold, cruel world.  Definitely my favorite hotel in New York.  They accomplish something most hotels cannot - when you walk through the doors you feel as if you have come home.

title: What a special retreat!
text: Stayed here for 1 night for a get-together with 2 friends. It's a very special place. It's quiet and elegant and away from the noise of midtown. The king bedded room, tho not enormous was more than adequate with elegant bed linens and lots of storage space. The bathroom, which looked, recently renovated, is luxurious--TV above bathtub and large stall shower. Didn't want to leave! The staff is welcoming and friendly. Wonderful bartender and excellent breakfast. It's just a special place.

title: Feels like home - a terrific one
text: When you walk down the steps from 63rd Street to the Lowell's small lobby you feel as if you're coming home from the storm of the city.  The desk people are welcoming, the concierge is knowledgeable and "wired," the doorman and porters greet you pleasantly.  When you get to your suite, assuming you have treated yourself to one, you wonder if you'd just as soon stay for a loong while.  We've been coming to the Lowell for a few decades, and the place has maintained a delightfully high level of service all that time.  The rooms have been refurbished more than once during that period.  The latest do-over was A+ with respect to the bathroom in our last suite -- a very worldly friend commented, on seeing the bathroom, "I want a bathroom just like this!"  Our bed had about 10 pillows on it, making choosing just the right one a snap.  Usually higher rooms are hotter (hot air rises, after all) but to our delight our suite on the 14th floor was not unpleasantly warm.  The hotel only has two tiny elevators, one of which is not infrequently out of service, which is inconvenient, but the only fly I can identify in this particular ointment -- or, rather, balm.

title: Warm and cozy
text:
I stayed at Lowell during a business trip.
The hotel is perfectly located in an elegant residential area right east of central park south. You just need 2 block to reach the underground. When in nyc, avoid midtown, too bustling.

The hotel itself is very elegant, boutique size, intimate. The staff is extremely welcoming, professional yet friendly.
I had a deluxe room and it was a perfect size.

I will be back!

title: The Lowell is understated, elegant, and becomes your personal pied a terre in a lovely and convenient east side neighborhood.
text:
I believe we've been staying at the Lowell for approximately 15 years, usually visiting in the spring and fall.  My wife and I have a favorite one-bedroom suite that we request, which is particularly nice in cool fall weather with its wood-burning fireplace. The suite has been totally renovated with a beautiful and spacious white marble bathroom and granite topped kitchenette. We use the Lowell as our base on these 5 night trips for forays to the theater, museums, restaurants and socializing with friends who are lucky enough to call NYC home. The Lowell is a welcome and ultra-comfortable respite from busy days and nights. We have also used it to host small cocktail gatherings in our suite, or order pizza up and watch a movie with friends. As I said, it feels like home and it's a tranquil and inviting respite to busy days and nights in the city. But above all, the real gems of the Lowell are its staff. 
These people are there to serve in a friendly and professional manner. They're down to earth, but exacting in executing your wishes and making you feel welcome and very special. From desk managers, to doormen, to bell men, to waiters and housekeeping, we see very little turnover from year to year. I assume the Lowell personnel are treated well, enjoy their jobs, and therefore reciprocate to their guests. The concierges, John Mark and Philip, are outstanding resources, well connected, and eager to advise and facilitate.  The Lowell is a small hotel with approximately 4 rooms or suites per floor on 17 floors. It is an old building, but gracious and elegant. If you enjoy your hotels large, sleek, and bustling, this isn't what you're looking for. If you want highly personal attention, elegantly timeless ambience, and a stellar east side location between Park and Madison, this is your place. However, like most things dear and unique, it comes at a price, and it will get your attention depending on what type of accommodation you 
choose. But, that is a matter of choice, personal prioritiy and most likely frame of mind. The Lowell offers my wife and I everything we're looking for in NYC and we always look forward to coming back.

title: Comfortable caring and central
text: Our first visit to the Lowell was a great success. Service, accommodation and location all met our expectations.  We shall return !

title: Comme à la maison à NYC !
text: L'hotel est charmant, les chambres sont spatieuses ainsi que les salles de bain ce qui est rare à NYC. Le seul petit hic se sont les concierges qui clairement travaillent en trainant les pieds ! Nous sommes resté au Lowell avec nos enfants du 22 octobre au 30 octobre et nous aurions aimé avoir un peut plus d'attention pour le service de conciergerie !

title: Absolutely Amazing!
text: I recently stayed here for the weekend with some girlfriends.  We stayed in a one bedroom suite.  Everything from the lobby to the room was absolutely amazing.  The bellman greeted me before I was even out of the cab and check in was a breeze.  The staff were polished, professional and warm.  Upon entering the suite, Tony offered to light the fireplace for me.....amazing!  I was also offered a beverage of my choice which was complimentary.  This hotel is absolutely beautiful....the rooms were like an apartment and were quite cozy and contemporary.  It is a great location on the upper east side and easily accessible to all the shopping on Madison Ave.  Despite being in the middle of Manhattan, it was unbelievably quiet!  I will definitely be back and most definitely recommend to anyone I can!

title: Best area and best hotel
text: Stayed at The Lowell September 2011 for 5 days. Service and room impeccable and the upper east side simply the most desirable part of NYC. Thanks to all at the Lowell. Even down to the cold water as we left in the limo. A stay we wont forget.

title: Charming hotel with great service
text: The rooms were very charming and extremely cosy, made me feel right at home! The staff were extremely friendly and helpful, will definitely be back!

title: A quiet and professional oasis in NYC
text: The location of the Lowell offers something rare in New York- quiet while still being close to attractions.  It is in a residential neighborhood, away from the garbage trucks and sirens that are typical almost everywhere else.  The hotel small, about 50 rooms, so  the staff recognize you, and know your name.  The decor is classic, but does not feel old.  Our room was updated with a bath that matches what you'd find in a Four Seasons or Ritz property.  The restaurant was excellent, fitness center was fine, and the concierge was able to find face-price tickets for one of the harder shows in the city.  Walk 1/2 block and you are on Madison Avenue, a bit further an you are near Central Park and the many museums.  i

title: THE best Hotel in NYC.  Period.
text:
I could not disagree with "areviewer"'s review (talk about awkward english).

If you read my review on The Surrey Hotel, I say it is my second favourite hotel in New York.....I don't mention my favourite.

Somethings you must keep sacred, but then after reading what "areviwer" wrote, I felt compelled to spill the beans.

There is a bar..... and a restaurant (one of the best in the city) but discreet.
Did I say best in NYC? .... I mean in America.   I'm actually quoting Wine Spectator, Esquire magazine and NYTimes.  This is where real NYers dine.

The rooms are DIVINE! 
You feel as if you are in your own pied a terre.

I could go on and on..... but I will allow you to find out for yourself.

This property is the standard that I compare all Hotel experiences to.
Period.

title: Great location but not what I expected
text:
The hotel's location is fantastic however -the following points should be considered before booking:

1. It is very discrete - however, the service for me was a bit impersonal at times
2. The hotel has more of a serviced apartment/ B&B feel - this is fine if its what you are looking for - but a bit souless. The public areas are very small and there is no bar 
4. The decor in the public areas as well as the restaurant is dated - lots of floral patterns and chintz
5. The rooms are very well appointed and reasonably large - do ask for one of the renovated ones

I am glad I experienced The Lowell - but for me - if you are looking at staying in this area - The Surrey does it much better at a lesser price. Even if both were the same price I would go for the surrey

title: A hidden gem
text: Boutique hotels nowadays try to be edgy and modern but this hotel is a classic hidden gem. I've been staying in so many contemporary style hotels lately I forgot how lovely it can be to stay somewhere with old world charm. Every touch speaks quality, Bulgari amenities, soft fluffy towels embroidered with "L", Wedgewood cutlery...  The only flaw I could find in this hotel was the tv in the bathroom. It is mounted above the tub but if you're inside the tub you can't see anything because it doesn't tilt down.  Otherwise everything was fabulous.

title: The best hotel in NYC
text: The Lowell is like having your own apartment in the Upper East Side. The rooms are large, luxe, spotless, cozy, and there is a little kichenette in each room. The location is perfect, right on 63rd and Madison, easy to get to theater or downtown. The people at the desk and Concierge are always helpful as are the doormen. And internet is free, as it should be.

title: The quintescence of a boutique hotel
text:
I recently stayed in this wonderful and real Boutique Hotel in New York, the building has a lot of charm and the location is so elegant upper east side. 
The staff is really nice, having real attention to the guests. The rooms and bathroom are very comfortable and large, even if mine was bit noisy due to the central AC in the backyard.
The reception area is small yet very charming and you feel at home with the scents of fresh flowers, soft drinks available. 
I do regret the breakfast which is quite poor for the price.

title: lovely
text: Wow.  Worth the money.  We've stayed there several times and have never been disappointed.  Stayed in one of their smallest, least expensive rooms and it was beautiful and well appointed.  Only "problem" was that the view from the window looked down upon other exterior walls, not the street, but this meant the room was extraordinarily quiet for NYC.  The service is wonderful; they manage to meet and anticipate every need without being obsequious or fawning.  A gem of a NY hotel.

title: Above expectations
text: Junior suite is definitely worth it. Wonderfull accomodations, service, and hospitality. Best location for designers shopping spree.

title: Fabulous Boutique Hotel
text: This Hotel is truly a gem! Discreet with understated elegance and low key luxury. If you are looking for flashy this is not the place to go but if you love discretion, class and efficency this hotel has it all. My room although rather small was very comfortable with good closet space and the kitchenette was really a plus. Service is exceptional in all aspects. As for location it is not the best for me as I generally prefer to be closer to downtown, but it is a short walking distance to the subway and many bus lines on Lex, Madison and Fifth.

title: Small and expensive, but the service is exceptional.
text: The rooms are on the small side, although the bathrooms are quite large for NYC.  In addition, you will pay a pretty penny to stay here.  Setting aside these issues, if money is no object this is a great option -- the service is wonderful.  The staff goes out of their way to meet guests' every need, the room service is on-point (especially for a small hotel), and housekeeping is meticulous in their cleaning of rooms and facilities.  The location of the hotel is also quite stellar, right off Madison Avenue.  And if you like to smoke cigars, Club Macanudo is next door.

title: Quiet, Low-Key and Comfortable
text:
I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at The Lowell. It provides under-stated luxury in a quiet and comfortable manner. It's located in a quiet residential neighborhood on 63rd between Madison & Park. There are lots of good restaurants within a short walking distance. The subway is two blocks to the F line at 63rd and about 5 blocks to the Lex lines at 59th. Arriving and departing from JFK is easy using the F & E lines.

My room had comfortable seating, a separate shower with a great head and lots of hot water. Toiletries are over-sized Bulgari. Internet access is free, but had some hiccups. It worked fine most of the time, but sometimes was slow for logging on and downloading. Room lighting is excellent--there are bright lights everywhere, with dimmers on the two bathroom switches. My room was spacious. Decor is homey with furnishings in good condition and the room was clean and well maintained. Breakfast and the concierge were both excellent.

On the less favorable side, the thermostats did not seem to be accurate and I had to set them extra high to get the room warm enough. It was ok when I did that. The HVAC is an upgraded window-type unit that produces a draft if you're near it. But it is quiet. The fireplace created a smoky odor even though I never used it. There was an air purifier in the room, but it didn't seem to do much even though I kept it on most of the time. The room smelled as smoky when I left as when I arrived. I recommend a room without a fireplace.

All in all, I liked The Lowell and will return.

title: It's always the best
text: We stayed here the first night of our honeymoon 12 years ago. I'm a native New Yorker, and have never been disappointed.  This hotel is brilliant through and through. From the amenities, to the decor of the rooms each is individually appointed with the ultimate in taste. We have come on innumerable trips to New York from Philly, my family lives in NYC, and have always been pleased with everything. A small discreet hotel with all the amenities of a larger chain. Location is terrific, midtown close to everything we needed. We come back time and again and are always thrilled. We just discovered the hotel is dog friendly so we may even bring our dogs on our next trip. Apparently the concierge will walk the dogs for you--how great is that? You cannot beat this hotel for its charm and service it raises the bar to any other hotel in the city.

title: Class and service
text:
We stayed at The Lowell for one night. A friend of us recommended the hotel. As a surprise we recieved an upgrade to a suite. The suite was magnificent and decorated by a famous interiour decorator. 
The style of the hotel is English with a tearoom in English style. Also our suite was in English style, but with a modern touch. The location of the hotel is very centered in on the Upper East side. Fairly close to subway and close to shopping and Central Park. Also by taxi it takes about 30-45 minutes to JFK, which we heard is fairly short. 
The service was very good, the staff was very polite. We experienced three little flaws which were that we had to call reception for our complementary welcome drink and the roomservice we orderd at night took about 45 min in stead of the prommised 30 min. The third thing is that the wireless internet wasn't working very well, but we were in no immediate need for that. 
The staff at the frontdesk was very helpfull and always asked if we needed anything. The hotel is very nice and an absolute must go if you want to spend a nice, discrete, quiet and relaxing holiday in NYC.

title: Intimate with a superb location
text: My husband and I really enjoyed our most recent stay at The Lowell.  We typically get a room with a bedroom, living room, kitchenette and fireplace.  It is such a lovely, intimate respite with low-key staff and a location that really works for us.  It is pricey, even by NYC standards, but we are never disappointed.

title: Classic five star hotel, elegant, discreet, comfortable.
text: If you prefer classic over modern fusion, this is the right hotel to stay at. A truly proper, elegant five star hotel with spacious rooms and an unbeatable location. Some of the rooms are better than others, but there's just no way to go wrong. Staff is high quality, polite unlike many other places that seem to be cutting corners these days.

title: Charming
text: We checked in at the The Lowell after a dismal night at Le Parker Meridien. We were looking for a comfortable, elegant, up-scale hotel room in a small hotel and we found just that The Lowell. We found the staff to be extremely friendly and hospitable....far from snobby as another reviewer mentioned. This is a special place where one can escape the busy city outside its doors.

title: Exceptionally elegant
text: The Lowell is a beautiful hotel in the heart of New York's exclusive Upper East Side. We have just returned from a one-night stay in a junior suite there and were incredibly impressed. As we entered our suite we were quite simply blown away by its sheer size and the attention to detail. Complimentary champagne and a fruit bowl awaited us and there was a fully stocked mini-bar. The bed was amazingly comfortable - one of the comfiest I have ever slept in - and we were made to feel like a king and queen with the level of service we received. In the marble bathroom were Bulgari toiletries, two washbasins, a huge shower room and a bathtub with a flatscreen television embedded into the wall. We could not have asked for more. The hotel is mere moments away from all of Park and Madison Avenue's designer stores and is an ideal base for exploring all of New York's sights. If you're looking for luxury, choose The Lowell.

title: The Lowell is an example of Upper East Side class
text: The Lowell is one of my favorite hotels in New York. Having also stayed at the Carlyle and the St. Regis, the Lowell is certainly in this category. While hidden off Madison Avenue and in the low 60's, the intimate hotel has a great staff and my favorite parts, the suites and Pembrooke Room. The suites are newly renovated, tastefully decorated and extremely spacious. They feel like apartments with their little kitchens and gorgeous bathrooms! And now my second favorite part, the Pembrooke Room. It is the ultimate setting for breakfast in New York. Afternoon Tea is also served fantastically. The room is hidden on the second floor at the back of the hotel and is decorated in lovely light spring colors and mirrored. There is tons of daylight on a sunny day. There are not that many amenities within the hotel because of it's size but the Post House. A Smith and Wollensky operation, it is just as good as their signature restaurant or Park Avenue Winter/Spring/Summer/Fall. A lot of celebrities like the bar because of it's privacy and charm. I absolutely love this hotel, there are not that many other hotels in New York like it. Even the Carlyle and the St. Regis can offer the same amount of luxury but not the same amount of intimacy.

title: On the fence about this hotel...
text:
Depending on your tastes, you will either love this hotel or hate it. I stayed here for 3 nights a few months ago. It was a good stay, but definitely not worth the price in my opinion. 

This Lowell Hotel is pretty small and low key. The location is great, it's 2 blocks from Central Park in the upper east side. The neighborhood is very residential and not as touristy as other areas of Manhattan. The hotel is right in the middle of a residential street.

The lobby is small and pretty dark. So are the hallways and the elevators. The front desk staff is nice, but a bit snobby which I will elaborate on later. 

The rooms are very nice. We got the cheapest one, so it was pretty small. The bed was big and comfy. The kitchenette is stocked with snacks and drinks but they're pretty expensive. ($5 for a little bottle of water). The bathroom is amazing and probably my favorite thing about the room. There isn't much of a view, just the apartments across the street. This hotel isn't a high rise so you won't get a pretty view of Manhattan like other hotels.

What I didn't like was how snobby the staff and other guests were. My boyfriend and I being 21 years old definitely got some condescending looks. It's kind of hard to explain through typing but you'll know when it happens. 

So if you're a bit older, like low key, non touristy 5 star hotels, then you will love the Lowell Hotel. If you're younger and want to be in the hustle and bustle of Manhattan this isn't the hotel to stay at.

It's a good hotel but I wouldn't stay here again.

title: Not what we'd hoped for.
text:
This was our first stay at The Lowell and we won't be back. We like trying 5-star hotels around the world (for example, in NYC we've previously stayed at the Trump twice and The Carlyle, and enjoyed both) and based on reviews we've read both here and elsewhere, we had high expectations of The Lowell. Unfortunately, we went away disappointed.

We had booked a Lowell King room through the American Express FHR program and we were upgraded to a Junior Suite. It was pleasantly decorated and fairly spacious, but overall there was nothing special about it. There was no view (in fact, we were looking straight into surrounding apartments and thus had no privacy unless we kept the curtains closed), no fireplace, no terrace. It just didn't "wow" us (unlike the 1-bedroom suite we usually get for less money at Trump, with fantastic views of Columbus Circle).

We didn't like the Pembroke room, where breakfast and tea are served. It is in a dark, semi-basement location with heavy draperies and an overdone decor (tassles everywhere). We found it dismal. The food was okay but the service was only so-so.

In fact, the biggest disappointment about The Lowell was the service. At such a small hotel, with a tiny lobby, guests should expect to be greeted personally by the front desk as they walk by on the way to the elevators. During our entire stay, we were NEVER greeted. In fact, they didn't even make eye contact. There always seemed to be several people behind the desk, but they were all busy talking with each other. Our one request to the concierge was handled pleasantly but impersonally. The most personable people on staff were the doormen, and even they were not all that friendly. We've had much nicer experiences elsewhere.

In short, we just didn't enjoy our experience at The Lowell.

title: A quiet, lovely spot to stay, and hard to top!
text: I've never stayed at a NYC hotel before, and chose this for location to the park, and for being slightly out of the midtown hustle.  Perfect choice.  Small, personal, absolutely lovely.  We were immediately upgraded at booking to a Junior Suite.  Not enormous, but spacious with a closet kitchen, gorgeous bath (separate tub and shower), room service, attentive conceirge.  Loved the bed and pillows.  Value?  I have nothing to compare it to, but this was above midrange during online research.

title: Romantic and comfortable
text: My husband and I stayed at the Lowell Hotel to celebrate his birthday this past December.  We had a lovely experience.
